Literature Review: The study of local DNA backbone conformation and conformational disorder is pivotal for understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying genome expression, regulation, and repair. Recent advancements in spectroscopic methods have provided new insights into these processes, particularly at single-stranded–double-stranded DNA (ssDNA–dsDNA) junctions. This literature review focuses on the application of site-specific exciton-coupled dimer probe spectroscopy, a novel approach that combines linear absorbance, circular dichroism spectroscopy, and nonlinear 2D fluorescence spectroscopy to investigate the local conformations and conformational disorder of DNA sugar-phosphate backbones. The use of exciton-coupled cyanine (iCy3)2 dimer probes has emerged as a powerful tool in this context, offering detailed information on the mean local conformations and conformational distributions of dsDNA at critical positions. The integration of these spectroscopic techniques allows for a comprehensive analysis of DNA breathing, a phenomenon that plays a crucial role in the assembly and function of protein–DNA complexes. DNA breathing refers to the transient opening of the double helix, which facilitates the access of proteins to specific DNA sequences. The ability to probe these dynamic processes at a molecular level has significant implications for our understanding of DNA replication, repair, and the regulation of gene expression. The application of (iCy3)2 dimer probes in conjunction with advanced spectroscopic methods has revealed the structural flexibility of the DNA backbone, highlighting the importance of conformational disorder in mediating protein–DNA interactions. These findings suggest a structural framework that could explain how DNA breathing drives the formation and function of protein–DNA complexes. Furthermore, the site-specific labeling of DNA with (iCy3)2 dimers enables the precise localization of conformational changes, providing insights into the mechanisms by which proteins recognize and bind to specific DNA sequences. This review underscores the potential of exciton-coupled dimer probe spectroscopy as a versatile and sensitive approach for studying the dynamic nature of DNA and its interactions with proteins. By elucidating the roles of local DNA backbone conformations and conformational disorder in biological processes, this research contributes to a deeper understanding of the molecular basis of genome maintenance and expression.
